file_insights.purpose: Define shared TypeScript interfaces and types for form input components

patterns_discovered.description: All input component props extend a common BaseInputProps interface containing shared properties like label, error, helperText, required, disabled, id, name, and className
patterns_discovered.benefit: Ensures consistency across all form inputs and reduces duplication

patterns_discovered.description: Component-specific props interfaces (TextInputBaseProps, SelectInputBaseProps, etc.) extend BaseInputProps and add type-specific properties and callbacks
patterns_discovered.benefit: Provides type-safe, component-specific configurations while maintaining consistency

patterns_discovered.description: SelectOption and SelectInputBaseProps use TypeScript generics (T = string) to support flexible value types
patterns_discovered.benefit: Allows reusable selection components with different value types

patterns_discovered.description: All interfaces and properties include JSDoc comments explaining their purpose
patterns_discovered.benefit: Improves developer experience and code discoverability

gotchas_discovered.description: SelectOption<T = string> and SelectInputBaseProps<T = string> have default generic parameters. Developers need to be aware that explicitly providing a type parameter is needed for non-string values
gotchas_discovered.mitigation: Documentation and IDE intellisense will guide developers

gotchas_discovered.description: FileInputValue is defined as File | File[] | null, which means consumers must handle all three states (single file, multiple files, no file)
gotchas_discovered.mitigation: Type safety enforces proper handling; documentation is clear about the union

gotchas_discovered.description: SelectInputBaseProps.onChange accepts T | T[] due to multiple selection support, which differs from TextInputBaseProps.onChange that only accepts string
gotchas_discovered.mitigation: Proper typing ensures compiler catches misuse; clear interface naming differentiates the patterns

approach_outcome.summary: Successfully created a well-structured, type-safe foundation for form components
details: Established clear hierarchy with BaseInputProps as the common foundation
Created specialized interfaces for 6 different input types (text, textarea, select, checkbox, date picker, file upload)
Used TypeScript generics to support flexible type requirements
Added comprehensive JSDoc documentation for all exports
Followed consistent naming conventions (BaseProps suffix pattern)

recommendations.recommendation: Consider adding composition/utility types for common prop combinations (e.g., PasswordInputProps, NumberInputProps) as the implementation progresses
Add validation-related types to BaseInputProps or as separate validation interfaces (e.g., validation rules, async validators) for form-wide validation support
Define types for form state management and context providers that will consume these input component props
Consider adding explicit event handler types (e.g., onBlur, onFocus) to BaseInputProps for more complete input control
Add aria-* related properties to BaseInputProps (e.g., ariaLabel, ariaDescribedBy) to support better accessibility out of the box
